English:
Bees live together in large groups called colonies. Inside a hive, there is one queen bee who lays all the eggs. The worker bees collect nectar from flowers and bring it back to the hive. They also make honey and protect the hive from danger.
　When young bees are born, the workers feed and care for them. After the young bees grow strong enough, they begin to work for the colony. Each bee has a role, and together they keep the hive alive.

　子バチが生まれると、働きバチが世話をして育てます。子バチが十分に強くなると、群れのために働き始めます。それぞれのハチに役割があり、力を合わせて巣を守っているのです。

English:
Sushi is one of the most famous foods in Japan. Many people think that sushi started as a modern Japanese dish. However, its history is much older and quite different from what most imagine.
　At first, sushi was a way to preserve fish. People placed fish in rice and let it ferment so the fish could be eaten later. This style was very common in parts of Asia before sushi became popular in Japan.
　Later, Japanese cooks improved the method. They used fresh fish with rice and added vinegar for flavor. This change made sushi easier to eat and helped it become a special food enjoyed at celebrations.
　Today, sushi is loved around the world. From simple rolls to expensive dishes, sushi continues to connect Japan with many cultures.

　もともと寿司は魚を保存する方法でした。人々は魚を米の中に入れて発酵させ、後で食べられるようにしました。この方法は、寿司が日本で広まる前にアジアの一部でよく使われていました。
　その後、日本の料理人たちはこの方法を改良しました。彼らは新鮮な魚を米と一緒に使い、味を良くするために酢を加えました。この変化によって寿司は食べやすくなり、お祝いの場で楽しまれる特別な料理になりました。
　今日では、寿司は世界中で愛されています。シンプルな巻き寿司から高級な料理まで、寿司は日本と多くの文化をつなぎ続けています。

English:
When I was studying abroad, I was invited to dinner by a host family. I tried to show my respect by finishing all the food on my plate. In Japan, this is often seen as polite.
　However, my host mother quickly asked me if I wanted more. She explained that in her country, leaving a little food means you are full, but finishing everything means you are still hungry. I realized that even simple table manners can have very different meanings.

　ところが、ホストマザーはすぐに「もっと食べたいの？」と尋ねました。彼女は、自分の国では少し残すのが満腹の合図で、全部食べきるのはまだ空腹だという意味だと説明しました。私は、食事のマナーのような単純なことでも、国によって意味が大きく違うのだと気づきました。

English:
Sleep is an essential part of our daily lives. It allows our bodies and minds to rest and recover from the day’s activities.
　Most adults need around seven to eight hours of sleep each night. Without enough rest, people may feel tired, have trouble focusing, or even become sick more easily.
　During sleep, the brain organizes memories and the body repairs itself. These are just a couple of good reasons to make sure you get a good night’s sleep.
Japanese:

　大人は通常、一晩に七〜八時間の睡眠を必要とします。十分に眠れないと、疲れを感じたり、集中できなかったり、病気にかかりやすくなったりします。
　睡眠中には、脳が記憶を整理し、体が修復されます。これらは、しっかり眠るべき理由のほんの一部です。

English:
Water is essential for all known forms of life. It makes up most of the human body and covers most of the Earth's surface.
　This simple liquid, however, can be difficult to classify. Is it a nutrient, a solvent, or both? Water helps carry nutrients through the body, but it also dissolves and removes waste.
　In large amounts, water can even be dangerous. Too much water in a short time can unbalance the body’s salts, which may lead to illness or even death. Thus, something so vital can also become harmful, depending on how it is used.

　大量に摂取すれば、水でさえ危険になり得る。短時間で過剰に摂取すると体内の塩分バランスが崩れ、病気や死につながることさえある。つまり、不可欠なものも使い方次第で有害になるのである。

English:
Have you ever wondered why sleep is so important? Most people know that sleep gives us rest and new energy for the next day. But that is not the only benefit. For example, during sleep our brains organize the memories we made while awake.
　Another function is related to growth and repair. The body fixes cells and tissues more effectively during deep sleep. Without enough rest, the immune system becomes weaker, and we may get sick more easily.
　Sleep can also influence our emotions. A person who lacks sleep may feel irritated or sad. On the other hand, good sleep often leads to calmness and clear thinking.

　もう一つの働きは成長と修復に関係しています。深い眠りの間に、体は細胞や組織をより効果的に修復します。十分な休養がなければ、免疫系は弱まり、病気にかかりやすくなるかもしれません。
　睡眠は私たちの感情にも影響を与えます。睡眠不足の人は、いらいらしたり悲しくなったりすることがあります。一方で、よく眠れば、落ち着きやすく、思考もすっきりするのです。

English:
Cats are loved all over the world. One of their most famous sounds is purring. People often think cats purr only when they are happy.
　In fact, cats also purr when they are sick or frightened. Some scientists believe that purring helps cats heal their bodies. The vibrations from purring may reduce stress and even repair bones.
　So, purring is not just a sign of joy. It is also a natural way for cats to take care of themselves.

　実際には、猫は病気のときや怖いときにも鳴きます。一部の科学者は、ゴロゴロ音が猫の体を癒すのに役立つと考えています。ゴロゴロの振動はストレスを減らし、骨を修復することさえあるかもしれません。
　ですから、ゴロゴロは喜びのサインだけではありません。それは猫が自分の体を守る自然な方法でもあるのです。

English:
Glass, a material we use every day, was once a rare and mysterious object. Long ago, in the lands near the Nile River, people first learned how to make it. They discovered that when sand was heated together with plant ash, it melted into a shiny, clear substance. At first, glass was used to make small beads for decoration.
　Over time, people improved their skills and created cups, bottles, and windows. The process was still difficult, and only the rich could afford glass items. If we travel to ancient ruins today, we may still find pieces of colored glass hidden in the soil. They remind us of the skill and patience of the early glassmakers.

　やがて人々は技術を高め、カップや瓶、窓を作るようになりました。その製法は依然として難しく、裕福な人しかガラス製品を持てませんでした。今日、古代の遺跡を訪れれば、土の中に隠れた色付きガラスのかけらを見つけられるかもしれません。それらは初期のガラス職人たちの技と忍耐を思い出させてくれます。

English:
Handwriting may reveal more about a person than we usually think. Some researchers have suggested that the way we write letters reflects our personality. For example, people who write with large letters are often seen as outgoing, while those who write small letters are thought to be more reserved.
　In addition, the pressure of the pen can also show emotional state. Heavy pressure may suggest determination, while light pressure may suggest sensitivity. If these ideas are supported by further studies, people might pay more attention not only to what they write but also to how they write it.

　さらに、ペンの筆圧も感情状態を示すことがあります。強い筆圧は決意を示し、弱い筆圧は繊細さを示すかもしれません。もしこれらの考えがさらなる研究で裏づけられれば、人々は「何を書くか」だけでなく「どう書くか」にも注意を払うようになるかもしれません。

English: When people talk about yawning, they often say it happens because we are tired or bored. This may sound like a simple explanation, but yawning is actually more complex than that. Scientists have found that yawning can also help cool the brain when its temperature rises. When we open our mouths wide and take in air, the cool air passes over blood vessels in the head. This process lowers brain temperature and may help us stay alert. The common expression "tired yawning" therefore reflects only part of the truth about why humans yawn.

People today are concerned about the environment. As a result, the practice of recycling has become more popular in many countries. But what exactly does recycling mean?
　It is probably easier to explain what recycling is not. Recycling does not simply mean throwing things away. Instead, it is the process of collecting used materials and turning them into new products. This reduces waste and saves resources. So, recycling is thought to be an important way to protect the environment.
　In the United States, about one-third of all waste is recycled. The U.S. government and local communities provide special bins and services to encourage people to recycle. At present, there are thousands of recycling centers across the country, and the number continues to increase every year.

English: Music, a form of sound organized by rhythm and melody, may have something to do with human memory. In an experiment, scientists played different kinds of music to two groups of students before a test. One group listened to calm classical music, and the other group listened to no music at all. Writing: 16_Why Sleep Matters for Children and Adults
English: Emma Lewis is the mother of two children, including six-year-old Daniel. According to sleep researchers, young children usually need about ten to twelve hours of sleep each night. Adults, on the other hand, generally require about seven to eight hours. However, says Dr. Karen Lee of Johns Hopkins University, many adults believe that they can train themselves to function well on only four or five hours of rest. "This is a dangerous myth," she explains. Even if people feel awake, the brain and body still suffer from a lack of proper sleep. Over time, this can increase the risk of heart disease, diabetes, and mental health problems.

Writing: 17_How Many Stars Are There in the Universe?（1）
English:
Astronomers often try to estimate the number of stars in the universe, but how many are there really? Most scientists agree that our own galaxy, the Milky Way, contains about 100 billion stars. They also believe that there are at least 100 billion other galaxies in the observable universe. If this is true, then the total number of stars could be more than the number of grains of sand on all the beaches of Earth. 
　But counting the stars is not an easy task. Some stars are so far away that their light has not yet reached us.

天文学者たちは宇宙にある星の数を推定しようとしますが、実際にはいくつあるのでしょうか。ほとんどの科学者は、私たちの銀河である天の川には約1,000億個の星があると考えています。また、観測可能な宇宙には少なくとも1,000億の銀河が存在すると考えられています。もしこれが正しければ、星の総数は地球上のすべての砂浜の砂粒より多いかもしれません。
　しかし、星の数を数えることは簡単な仕事ではありません。ある星はあまりに遠くにあり、その光がまだ地球に届いていません。

English:
In Mexico, for example, the Day of the Dead combines Catholic beliefs with ancient Aztec traditions. In India, the festival of Diwali is celebrated with lights and fireworks to symbolize the victory of good over evil. In Spain, running with the bulls in Pamplona is a famous tradition, though it has its roots in practical ways of moving cattle. 
　In many cultures, it is traditional to prepare special foods during festivals. This custom reflects the belief that sharing food strengthens family and community bonds. The use of bright colors, music, and dance is also common, since they are thought to drive away evil and invite good fortune. Though festivals in many parts of the world still continue to reflect ethnic, cultural, and religious backgrounds, contemporary celebrations often adapt their customs to suit modern values.

Writing: 21_The Importance of Sleep for Growing Children（1）
English:
When we look at children sleeping peacefully, we realize that through sleep they are preparing for life. They gain various physical benefits, such as muscle growth and tissue repair. They also gain mental benefits. For example, during deep sleep, the brain organizes memories and processes emotions. These physical and mental effects form part of the development that young children need in order to grow up.
　Just as food and play are important for children, so is sleep. But in present-day Japan, especially in cities, many children are not sleeping enough. Children need long hours of sleep for their mental and physical health. They need at least nine hours of sleep every night to support their growth.
Japanese:
子どもたちが安らかに眠っている姿を見ると、睡眠を通して彼らが人生の準備をしていることに気づきます。筋肉の成長や組織の修復といったさまざまな身体的な利益を得ています。また、精神的な恩恵も受けています。例えば、深い眠りの間に、脳は記憶を整理し感情を処理します。こうした身体的・精神的な効果は、子どもが成長するために必要な発達の一部をなしています。
　食事や遊びが子どもにとって重要であるのと同じように、睡眠も大切です。しかし現代の日本では、特に都市部で、多くの子どもが十分に眠れていません。子どもたちは心身の健康のために長時間の睡眠を必要とします。成長を支えるためには、毎晩少なくとも九時間の睡眠が必要です。

Writing: 22_The Importance of Sleep for Growing Children（2）
English:
Another point to consider is how children spend their evenings. Some researchers say that using smartphones or watching TV before bed reduces sleep quality. It is very doubtful, however, whether children can easily avoid these devices in daily life. Parents, worried about both study and entertainment, often allow their children to stay up later than recommended.
　What do these children do when they are not sleeping? They tend to spend time on games, social media, or television. These activities may be enjoyable, but they do not provide the deep rest that sleep gives. Healthy sleep can only be achieved by creating an environment with less stress and fewer electronic devices. Children need regular sleep habits that allow their bodies and minds to recover fully each night.
Japanese:
もう一つ考えるべき点は、子どもたちが夕方をどう過ごすかです。
研究者の中には、寝る前にスマートフォンを使ったりテレビを見たりすると睡眠の質が低下すると指摘する人もいます。
しかし、子どもたちが日常生活でこうした機器を簡単に避けられるかどうかは非常に疑わしいです。
勉強や娯楽の両方を気にかける親は、推奨よりも遅くまで子どもを起きさせることがよくあります。
　では、眠っていないときにこれらの子どもたちは何をしているのでしょうか。
彼らはゲームやソーシャルメディア、テレビに時間を費やしがちです。
これらの活動は楽しいかもしれませんが、睡眠が与える深い休養を得ることはできません。
健やかな眠りは、ストレスが少なく電子機器の影響が少ない環境を整えることでしか得られません。
子どもたちは、毎晩心身を十分に回復させる規則正しい睡眠習慣を必要としています。

English:
There is much discussion about the roots of the game of basketball. Some people say that games similar to modern basketball were played in Central America thousands of years ago. 
　In comparison to modern basketball, the Mayan game of pok-ta-pok was played with a heavy rubber ball. The players tried to hit the ball through a stone ring that was fixed high on a wall. The game was usually played by teams, and it often had religious or ceremonial meanings.
　In North America, Native Americans had their own traditional ball games. One popular version involved throwing a small ball toward a wooden target. These games were not only for fun but also for teaching teamwork and endurance.

The modern version of basketball was created in 1891 by James Naismith, a Canadian physical education teacher. He used a soccer ball and two peach baskets as goals for his first game. At that time, the game was simple, but it quickly grew in popularity in schools and colleges.
　By the early 20th century, basketball had spread beyond North America. Rules were established to prevent rough play, such as striking or kicking. This is where basketball became recognized as a modern, organized sport enjoyed all over the world.

English:
A dragonfly can do one thing extremely well: hunt. Recently scientists reported that dragonflies are among the most effective predators in the animal kingdom. A dragonfly can capture prey in midair with an accuracy of over 95 percent. It can hover, fly straight backward, and even change direction in an instant. And its brain, though small, can process visual information incredibly fast.
　Researchers at Harvard University have studied how dragonflies achieve this level of control. They found that dragonflies use nearly all of their four wings independently. This allows them to glide smoothly, save energy, and still make sudden moves to catch prey.

English:
The past thirty to forty years have seen a sharp rise in the number of children who are overweight, and scientists are still studying the reasons. Some have pointed to reduced physical activity, but obesity is also common among children who live in rural areas, where there is often more space to play outside.
　A widely discussed explanation is the increase in the consumption of processed foods and sugary drinks. Children today often eat fast food more frequently than in the past, and many drink soft drinks every day. This change in diet means that children take in more calories than they can use, which leads to weight gain.

English: Children who spend hours watching TV or playing video games are less active.
Japanese: 何時間もテレビを見たりビデオゲームをしたりする子どもたちは、運動量が少なくなります。

English: This makes it harder for them to maintain a healthy balance between diet and exercise.
Japanese: そのため、食事と運動の健康的なバランスを保つことが難しくなります。

English: Scientists agree that a combination of diet, activity level, and lifestyle changes is driving the increase in childhood obesity.
Japanese: 科学者たちは、食事、活動量、そして生活習慣の変化の組み合わせが子どもの肥満増加を引き起こしていると一致して考えています。

English: There is also evidence that genetics, family income, and the food environment in schools may play a role.
Japanese: また、遺伝、家庭の収入、さらには学校での食環境も関係しているという証拠もあります。

English: Thus, although diet and exercise are central issues, we cannot yet say that they are the only reasons for the rapid rise in childhood obesity.
Japanese: したがって、食事と運動が中心的な問題であることは確かですが、子どもの肥満が急増している理由がそれだけであるとはまだ言えません。

English: People may decide to study mathematics for various reasons. They may do so in order to pass important examinations at school or university, or to prepare for future studies in science and engineering. Business people may need to understand statistics and data analysis in order to make better financial decisions. Scientists may realize the importance of using mathematics to describe natural phenomena and to test their theories accurately. Ordinary people may also find that basic mathematical skills are necessary for daily life, such as calculating expenses or understanding information in the news.

English:
Learning mathematics implies entering a new way of thinking, and it inevitably leads to the development of logical reasoning. Learning mathematics well enough to solve problems and apply concepts is such demanding training that we need some strong motivation to continue. The four distinct but related areas of mathematics — arithmetic, algebra, geometry, and statistics — require regular, preferably daily, practice. These areas are connected in various ways with important aspects of study, such as accuracy, creativity, problem-solving, and abstraction.
　Learning mathematics calls for no extraordinary talent, but it does demand patience and steady effort. It requires careful observation, the ability to recognize patterns, and the willingness to think deeply about abstract ideas. Above all, it requires a lively interest in the many ways numbers and structures can describe the world around us.

数学を学ぶということは、新しい思考法に入ることであり、それは必然的に論理的推論力の発達につながります。問題を解き、概念を応用できるまで数学を学ぶことは非常に大変な訓練であり、それを続けるには強い動機が必要です。算数、代数学、幾何学、統計学という四つの異なるが関連する分野は、規則的に、できれば毎日の練習を必要とします。これらの分野は、正確さ、創造性、問題解決、抽象化といった学習の重要な側面とさまざまな形で結びついています。

English:
On November 26, 2011, NASA launched the Mars Science Laboratory, a mission that carried the rover Curiosity to the Red Planet. The spacecraft traveled more than 560 million kilometers before landing on August 6, 2012, inside Gale Crater. The successful landing was celebrated as one of the most complex space operations ever attempted by NASA.
　Curiosity, about the size of a car, was designed to study the Martian surface and search for evidence that the planet once supported life. Its arrival marked the beginning of a new chapter in planetary exploration, combining engineering innovation with scientific ambition. The rover carried advanced instruments, including cameras, spectrometers, and drills, to analyze rocks and soil directly on Mars.
Japanese:
2011年11月26日、NASAは「マーズ・サイエンス・ラボラトリー」を打ち上げ、キュリオシティ探査車を火星へ送り出した。宇宙船は5億6000万キロメートル以上を旅し、2012年8月6日にゲール・クレーターに着陸した。その成功は、NASAが試みた中で最も複雑な宇宙作戦の一つとして祝われた。
　車の大きさほどのキュリオシティは、火星表面を調べ、かつて生命を支えた証拠を探すために設計された。その到着は、工学の革新と科学的野心を組み合わせた惑星探査の新しい章を意味した。探査車にはカメラや分光器、ドリルなどの先進的な機器が搭載され、火星の岩石や土壌を直接分析できた。

English:
For several hours after its arrival, mission control at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory monitored every signal carefully. Scientists and engineers cheered as the rover confirmed its systems were working, and soon the first images of Mars appeared on screens. These pictures showed a barren landscape, yet one filled with clues about the planet’s ancient environment.
　In a later interview, NASA scientist John Grotzinger recalled the tension of the “seven minutes of terror” during Curiosity’s descent. The rover had to slow down from 20,000 kilometers per hour to zero, using a parachute, rockets, and a sky crane. “Once it touched the surface safely, we knew history had been made,” Grotzinger said.
Japanese:
到着後数時間、ジェット推進研究所の管制室では全ての信号が注意深く監視された。科学者や技術者たちは、探査車のシステムが正常に動作していることを確認すると歓声を上げた。そして間もなく、火星の最初の画像がスクリーンに映し出された。そこには荒涼とした風景が広がっていたが、惑星の古代環境に関する多くの手がかりも隠されていた。
　後のインタビューで、NASAの科学者ジョン・グロツィンガーは、キュリオシティの降下中に経験した「7分間の恐怖」を振り返った。探査車は時速2万キロからゼロまで減速する必要があり、パラシュート、ロケット、そしてスカイクレーンを使用した。「安全に地表に着陸した瞬間、歴史が作られたと確信した」と彼は語った。

English:
Two years after Curiosity’s landing, the rover discovered evidence of an ancient streambed and chemical ingredients necessary for life. NASA believed that these results could renew public interest in space exploration and justify the expense of future missions. The agency also planned new spacecraft, such as the Perseverance rover, to continue the search for signs of life and prepare for human exploration.
　The outcome was more than scientific achievement. Space exploration was a vital part of NASA’s identity, a source of national pride, and a foundation for future cooperation with international partners. And proving that life might once have existed on Mars was as important to the agency as inspiring a new generation to dream of the stars.

English:
Although elephants are the largest land animals, they are also known for their strong memories. Researchers have reported that elephants can remember the locations of water holes even after many years. For instance, during a long drought in Africa, an old female elephant led her herd across the desert to a water source she had visited in her youth.
　Elephants also appear to recognize human voices and faces. In some studies, they reacted more calmly to the voices of friendly people but became cautious when they heard the voices of strangers. There are even stories of elephants showing kindness toward humans. One traveler once fell asleep under a tree, and an elephant gently pushed him with its trunk to wake him when a lion approached.
　Furthermore, elephants seem to understand simple instructions. Zookeepers report that elephants can respond to requests such as “Lift your foot” or “Bring the stick.” This ability, together with their memory, makes elephants not only powerful but also intelligent animals.
Japanese:
ゾウは陸上で最大の動物であるが、強い記憶力でも知られている。研究者たちは、ゾウが何年も前の水場の場所を覚えていると報告している。例えば、アフリカの長い干ばつの間、年老いたメスのゾウが若いころに訪れた水場へ群れを導いた。
　ゾウはまた、人間の声や顔を識別するように思われる。ある研究では、ゾウは親しい人の声には穏やかに反応したが、見知らぬ人の声を聞くと警戒した。ゾウが人間に優しさを示すという話もある。ある旅行者が木の下で眠っていたとき、ライオンが近づくと、ゾウが鼻でそっと押して彼を起こした。
　さらに、ゾウは簡単な指示を理解するようだ。動物園の飼育員は、ゾウが「足を上げて」や「棒を持ってきて」といった要求に応えることができると報告している。この能力と記憶力が合わさることで、ゾウは力強いだけでなく、知性のある動物となっている。

English:
Smell is one of the most ancient senses. Because of this, it can influence human emotions more deeply than we realize. In September 2001, researchers at Rockefeller University reported that people could identify more than 1 trillion different odors, far more than previously believed. The smell of freshly baked bread or a familiar perfume can instantly bring back memories and feelings from years ago.
　Smell also appears to affect men and women differently. In one study, scientists exposed volunteers to the scent of lavender and then measured their stress levels. The women showed a clear drop in blood pressure and reported feeling calmer. Men, however, did not respond in the same way and sometimes even reported slight irritation. Researchers suggest that cultural expectations may play a role in how each sex interprets and reacts to scents.
Japanese:
嗅覚は最も古い感覚の一つである。そのため、人間の感情に私たちが思う以上に深く影響を与えることがある。2001年9月、ロックフェラー大学の研究者たちは、人間が1兆種類以上の匂いを識別できると発表した。焼きたてのパンやなじみの香水の匂いは、何年も前の記憶や感情を即座に呼び起こすことができる。
　匂いはまた、男女で異なる影響を及ぼすようである。ある研究で、科学者たちは被験者にラベンダーの香りを嗅がせ、ストレスの程度を測定した。女性は血圧が明らかに下がり、より落ち着いたと報告した。しかし男性は同じ反応を示さず、わずかな苛立ちを訴えることさえあった。研究者たちは、この違いには文化的な期待が関係している可能性があると示唆している。

English:
Smell is also an important factor in social interaction. Experiments show that people are more likely to trust others in rooms with pleasant odors, such as citrus or vanilla, than in rooms with no scent. This may explain why some stores use subtle fragrances to encourage customers to stay longer and buy more products.
　How do you feel about smell and its influence? Do you notice how certain fragrances make you feel more relaxed or alert? Not everyone reacts in the same way. For some, the smell of coffee is energizing, while for others it may be overwhelming.
　In crowded environments, smell is unavoidable. Think about a busy subway at rush hour, filled with perfumes, sweat, and the aroma of food. People cannot escape these odors, but they can adapt. In Japan, for example, many commuters wear masks not only to avoid germs but also to reduce unpleasant smells. Anthropologists suggest that this practice helps people create a private space in public, allowing them to “smell without reacting.”
Japanese:
嗅覚は社会的交流においても重要な要素である。実験によると、シトラスやバニラのような快い香りのある部屋では、人々は他者をより信頼しやすい。このため、一部の店がかすかな香りを利用して、客が長く滞在し、より多くの商品を購入するよう促すのかもしれない。
　匂いとその影響について、あなた自身はどう感じるだろうか。特定の香りが自分をリラックスさせたり、逆に覚醒させたりするのに気づいているだろうか。すべての人が同じ反応を示すわけではない。コーヒーの香りが活力を与える人もいれば、強すぎると感じる人もいる。
　混雑した環境では、匂いを避けることはできない。ラッシュアワーの地下鉄を思い浮かべてほしい。香水、汗、食べ物の匂いが入り混じっている。人々はこうした匂いを避けられないが、適応することはできる。例えば日本では、多くの通勤者がマスクを着けるが、それは細菌を避けるだけでなく、不快な匂いを減らすためでもある。人類学者は、この習慣が公共の場でプライベートな空間を作り出し、人々が「反応せずに匂う」ことを可能にしていると指摘している。

English: Smell is also an important factor in social interaction.
Japanese: 嗅覚は社会的交流においても重要な要素である。

English: Experiments show that people are more likely to trust others in rooms with pleasant odors, such as citrus or vanilla, than in rooms with no scent.
Japanese: 実験によると、シトラスやバニラのような快い香りのある部屋では、人々は他者をより信頼しやすい。

English: This may explain why some stores use subtle fragrances to encourage customers to stay longer and buy more products.
Japanese: このため、一部の店がかすかな香りを利用して、客が長く滞在し、より多くの商品を購入するよう促すのかもしれない。

English: How do you feel about smell and its influence?
Japanese: 匂いとその影響について、あなた自身はどう感じるだろうか。

English: Do you notice how certain fragrances make you feel more relaxed or alert?
Japanese: 特定の香りが自分をリラックスさせたり、逆に覚醒させたりするのに気づいているだろうか。

English: Not everyone reacts in the same way.
Japanese: すべての人が同じ反応を示すわけではない。

English: For some, the smell of coffee is energizing, while for others it may be overwhelming.
Japanese: コーヒーの香りが活力を与える人もいれば、強すぎると感じる人もいる。

English: In crowded environments, smell is unavoidable.
Japanese: 混雑した環境では、匂いを避けることはできない。

English: Think about a busy subway at rush hour, filled with perfumes, sweat, and the aroma of food.
Japanese: ラッシュアワーの地下鉄を思い浮かべてほしい。香水、汗、食べ物の匂いが入り混じっている。

English: People cannot escape these odors, but they can adapt.
Japanese: 人々はこうした匂いを避けられないが、適応することはできる。

English: In Japan, for example, many commuters wear masks not only to avoid germs but also to reduce unpleasant smells.
Japanese: 例えば日本では、多くの通勤者がマスクを着けるが、それは細菌を避けるだけでなく、不快な匂いを減らすためでもある。

English: Anthropologists suggest that this practice helps people create a private space in public, allowing them to “smell without reacting.”
Japanese: 人類学者は、この習慣が公共の場でプライベートな空間を作り出し、人々が「反応せずに匂う」ことを可能にしていると指摘している。

English:
Movies are very much like theater in that they tell stories, create emotions, and bring people together, but in no way can they compare with the live, unpredictable experience of watching a play on stage. This is not the only reason why theater will never disappear, for a performance in front of an audience carries an energy that even the most advanced screen technology cannot reproduce. We can record a film and watch it many times, but the artistic quality of a one-time-only stage performance remains unique and unrepeatable. A well-directed play makes the act of watching important.
　Theater is still the most direct and personal means of conveying human expression, and this is what makes it valuable. The idea that actors and audience members share the same space, breathing the same air, is extraordinary. We take such immediacy for granted, not realizing that theater itself has undergone great transformations since the tragedies of ancient Greece and the works of Shakespeare in the seventeenth century.
Japanese:
映画は劇場にとてもよく似ていて、物語を語り、感情を生み、人々を結びつける。しかし、舞台で芝居を観るという生の、予測不可能な体験と比べることは決してできない。劇場がなくならないのはこのためだけではない。観客の前で演じられる舞台には、どれほど高度な映像技術でも再現できない力が宿っているからだ。映画は録画して何度でも観られるが、一度限りの舞台公演の芸術的な価値は唯一で、二度と繰り返すことはできない。よく演出された芝居は、観劇そのものを特別な行為にする。
　劇場は今なお、人間の表現を伝える最も直接的で個人的な手段であり、それが価値を持たせている。俳優と観客が同じ空間を共有し、同じ空気を吸っているという事実は驚くべきことである。私たちはこの即時性を当然のものと考えているが、劇場は古代ギリシアの悲劇や17世紀のシェイクスピアの作品以来、大きな変化を遂げてきた。

English:
Not only has the art and craft of stage production improved over the centuries, but the range of stories told on stage is astonishing. In fact, movies often depend on plays and scripts for inspiration, just as they rely on actors trained in theater to bring characters to life. Without the continuing creativity of playwrights and performers, cinema itself would lose much of its richness.
　Another important reason why theater will never disappear is because those who wish to act or direct often dream of presenting their work live before an audience — something immediate, fragile, and unforgettable. The artist may use lights, microphones, or even digital projections, but the finished product must eventually end up on a stage if it is to connect deeply with the audience. The artist may borrow techniques from film just as film borrows from theater, but the heart of the performance will still belong to the stage.

English:
Why is it that people who laugh often seem to recover more quickly from illness and cope better with stress? Doctors and psychologists have long suspected that humor may play an important role in maintaining good health. It has been suggested that laughter helps reduce tension and provides both physical and emotional relief. Indeed, many hospitals have even invited comedians or clowns to perform for patients in order to promote recovery.
　Recently, a group of researchers studied the effects of laughter on the immune system. In one experiment, volunteers were asked to watch either a funny movie or a neutral documentary. Blood samples taken afterwards showed that those who had watched the comedy displayed an increase in certain antibodies that protect the body from infection. In contrast, those who had watched the documentary showed no such change.
Japanese:
なぜよく笑う人は、病気から早く回復し、ストレスにもうまく対処できるように見えるのだろうか。医師や心理学者は長い間、ユーモアが健康維持に重要な役割を果たしているのではないかと疑ってきた。笑いは緊張を和らげ、身体的にも精神的にも安らぎをもたらすと考えられている。実際、多くの病院では患者の回復を促すために、コメディアンや道化師を招くことさえある。
　最近、研究者のグループが笑いと免疫系の関係を調べた。ある実験では、被験者におもしろい映画か中立的なドキュメンタリーを観てもらった。その後に採取した血液検査では、コメディを観た人は体を感染から守る特定の抗体が増加していることが示された。一方、ドキュメンタリーを観た人にはそのような変化は見られなかった。

English:
Another experiment examined how laughter influences pain tolerance. Participants who viewed humorous videos were able to keep their hands in ice-cold water for a longer time compared to those who watched serious programs. Although they did not always report feeling less pain at the moment, their bodies showed signs of reduced stress hormones and improved circulation. These physiological reactions suggest that laughter can strengthen the body’s natural defenses.
　The researchers conclude that laughter is more than just a pleasant reaction. It is a form of exercise for the body and a release for the mind. The message is clear: people should not underestimate the power of humor. Even if we cannot always change our problems, allowing ourselves to laugh may help us face them with greater strength and resilience.
Japanese:

　研究者たちは、笑いは単なる楽しい反応以上のものであると結論づけている。それは体にとっては運動であり、心にとっては解放である。メッセージは明確だ。人々はユーモアの力を過小評価すべきではない。たとえ問題を変えることができなくても、笑うことによってより強く、よりしなやかに立ち向かうことができるのだ。

English:
"The influence of music on learning has not been researched as thoroughly as the effects of reading or direct classroom teaching," researchers note in the Journal of Educational Psychology. "Nevertheless, most of the findings reported so far suggest that music can have measurable effects on concentration and memory." Among the observed benefits of listening to music are increases in mood, motivation, and even problem-solving ability. Some studies, however, have also found that very loud or fast music may distract students and reduce their ability to focus.
　According to a nationwide survey, male students often prefer energetic genres such as rock, hip-hop, and electronic dance music, while female students tend to choose softer styles like pop ballads, classical, or acoustic folk. Music is also tied to the use of digital devices, and young people’s interaction with streaming services and music apps may influence future career interests in sound engineering and media production, notes education professor Laura Mitchell of Ohio State University.
Japanese:
「音楽が学習に与える影響は、読書や直接的な授業の効果ほど徹底的には研究されていない」と教育心理学ジャーナルの研究者たちは述べている。「しかし、これまで報告されている結果の多くは、音楽が集中力や記憶力に測定可能な効果をもたらすことを示している。」音楽を聴くことで観察される利点には、気分ややる気の向上、さらには問題解決能力の強化が含まれる。しかし一部の研究では、非常に大きな音量や速いテンポの音楽が生徒を妨害し、集中力を低下させることも指摘されている。
　全国調査によると、男子学生はロック、ヒップホップ、エレクトロニックダンスなどのエネルギッシュなジャンルを好み、女子学生はポップバラード、クラシック、アコースティックフォークなどの穏やかなスタイルを選ぶ傾向がある。音楽はデジタル機器の利用とも結びついており、ストリーミングサービスや音楽アプリとの関わりが、将来の音響工学やメディア制作への関心に影響を与える可能性があると、オハイオ州立大学の教育学教授ローラ・ミッチェルは指摘している。

English:
“It seems that exposure to technology through music apps creates more opportunities for young people to develop technical skills,” says Mitchell. “If girls gain early access to these technologies, their interest may extend into professional fields related to audio design and digital communication.” If women play a greater role in music technology, they may produce tools that encourage collaboration and creativity rather than distraction.
　Music streaming platforms are now used in more than 85% of households with teenagers in the United States; they generated $4 billion in 2015 and more than $10 billion by 2020. “All signs suggest that the industry will continue expanding at a steady pace,” Mitchell explains. “The new challenge is to design music-based tools for classrooms that encourage students to engage more deeply with learning through rhythm, melody, and digital interaction.” Until then, researchers emphasize the need for greater awareness of both the positive and negative effects of music on students’ performance.
Japanese:
「音楽アプリを通じて技術に触れることが、若者に技術的スキルを育む機会を与えているようだ」とミッチェルは言う。「女子がこれらの技術に早くからアクセスすれば、その関心は音響デザインやデジタルコミュニケーションに関連する専門分野にまで広がる可能性が高い。」女性が音楽技術分野でより大きな役割を果たすようになれば、気を散らすのではなく、協力や創造性を促進するツールを生み出すかもしれない。
　現在、米国の10代を持つ家庭の85%以上で音楽ストリーミングプラットフォームが利用されており、その収益は2015年に40億ドル、2020年には100億ドルを超えた。「すべての兆候は、この産業が今後も着実に拡大を続けることを示している」とミッチェルは説明する。「新たな課題は、リズムやメロディー、デジタルな相互作用を通じて、生徒がより深く学習に関わることを促す音楽ベースの教育ツールを設計することだ。」それまでは、音楽が生徒の成績に与える肯定的および否定的な影響について、より大きな認識が必要であると研究者たちは強調している。

English:
Beware of those who use numbers in misleading ways to persuade you. Statistics can be powerful tools for understanding reality, but when they are presented without proper context, they can easily create a false impression. People who manipulate statistics often rely on the fact that many listeners will not ask deeper questions about where the numbers came from or what they really mean.
　For instance, imagine a company that announces, "Our sales increased by 100% last year!" That sounds like an amazing achievement, right? But later you discover that the company sold only ten products the year before, and twenty the following year. The statement was technically true, but without context it gave the impression of a massive success. In reality, the growth was very small compared to other businesses.

　例えば、ある会社が「昨年、売上が100％増加しました！」と発表したとしよう。それは驚くべき成果のように聞こえる。しかし後で、その会社が一昨年は10個しか商品を売らず、翌年は20個売っただけだと分かる。この発言は技術的には真実だが、文脈なしでは大成功の印象を与える。実際には、他の企業と比べれば成長はごく小さいものだった。

English:
Politicians also sometimes misuse statistics to gain support. Suppose a mayor says, "Crime in our city has dropped by 50% during my term." At first, that sounds impressive. However, if you later learn that the city changed the way crimes were recorded, you realize that the decrease did not mean fewer crimes, only different counting. The numbers were not lies, but they were used in a way that created a deceptive message.
　Advertising is another area where statistics are often abused. A food company may claim, "Nine out of ten people prefer our brand of cereal." What they don’t tell you is that only ten people participated in the survey, and nine of them were employees of the company. While the statement is factually correct, it is designed to mislead customers into believing the product is more popular than it really is.

English:
Have you ever thought about how education has changed with technology? In the past, most students could only study in classrooms, with teachers and textbooks. Today, "online learners" can take courses on the internet, while "traditional learners" still prefer classrooms. Online learners may enjoy freedom and flexibility, studying at their own pace.
　However, this approach is not perfect. Some students may struggle with motivation or feel isolated without classmates. Traditional learners, on the other hand, benefit from direct contact with teachers and friends. This method can help them stay motivated, but it often requires fixed schedules. We should understand the strengths and weaknesses of both online and traditional learning. Such awareness can help students choose the style that suits them best.

　しかし、この方法は完璧ではありません。クラスメートがいないために、やる気を失ったり孤立を感じたりする学生もいます。一方で、伝統的な学習者は教師や友人との直接的なつながりから利益を得ます。この方法はやる気を維持する助けになりますが、多くの場合、決まった時間割に従う必要があります。私たちは、オンライン学習と伝統的学習の長所と短所を理解するべきです。このような認識は、学生が自分に最も合った学習スタイルを選ぶ助けとなります。

English:
In the late 20th century, many experts worried that computers would replace human labor on a massive scale. Factories began to adopt industrial robots, and offices increasingly relied on software to perform tasks that once required large numbers of clerks. Yet, as in earlier periods of technological change, the disappearance of some jobs was balanced by the appearance of new ones. For example, the rise of personal computers created demand for programmers, network engineers, and IT support specialists. This pattern suggests that technology often changes the nature of work rather than eliminates it completely.
　In recent years, artificial intelligence has intensified these debates. AI can already write simple articles, recognize faces, and recommend products with remarkable accuracy. Self-driving cars, though not yet fully common, represent another step toward replacing certain forms of human labor. Some researchers argue that machines will soon rival humans in many areas, raising fears about widespread unemployment. Others, however, point out that human creativity, empathy, and judgment remain very difficult to automate.

20世紀後半、多くの専門家はコンピュータが大規模に人間の労働を置き換えるのではないかと心配した。工場では産業用ロボットが導入され始め、事務所ではかつて多くの事務員を必要とした作業をソフトウェアに依存するようになった。しかし、以前の技術革新の時代と同じように、いくつかの仕事が消える一方で、新しい仕事が生まれてその均衡が保たれた。たとえば、パソコンの普及はプログラマーやネットワークエンジニア、ITサポートの専門家への需要を生み出した。このことは、技術は仕事を完全に消すのではなく、その性質を変えることが多いことを示している。
　近年、人工知能はこうした議論をさらに激化させている。AIはすでに簡単な記事を書いたり、顔を認識したり、驚くほどの精度で商品を推薦したりすることができる。自動運転車はまだ広く普及していないが、人間の労働の一部を置き換えるもう一つの段階を示している。一部の研究者は、機械がまもなく多くの分野で人間に匹敵すると主張しており、広範な失業への恐れを引き起こしている。しかし一方で、人間の創造性や共感、判断力は自動化することが非常に難しいと指摘する人もいる。

English:
At the same time, history shows that people often value human presence in economic activities. Concerts, museums, and sporting events continue to attract large audiences not only because of the content but also because of the shared social experience. In the service industry, many customers prefer direct contact with staff, appreciating the warmth of human hospitality. Even in highly automated systems, such as online shopping, customer service agents play a key role in building trust. These examples indicate that demand for human interaction is unlikely to disappear.
　Looking forward, the challenge is to adapt to the rapid pace of technological progress. Governments and schools will need to provide opportunities for workers to reskill and learn new abilities. Employers will also need to recognize the importance of human qualities that machines cannot easily replicate. Rather than viewing automation as a threat, society may come to see it as a tool that frees people from routine labor. In this way, the future of human work will likely be shaped by a balance between efficiency and human connection.

English: You are walking through a crowded street market filled with sounds and smells from every direction. You find yourself cheering as well, even though you had not intended to. Why? Imitation. Later in the day, at a supermarket, you notice several shoppers placing reusable bags into their carts. Imitation, closely connected to the process of social learning, plays a powerful role in how humans judge what is correct, acceptable, or useful. When a large number of people support an idea or behave in a particular way, others are more likely to see that action as logical or valuable. The greater the number of individuals acting in the same way, the stronger the influence becomes on those observing them. This tendency explains why fashion trends spread so rapidly, why investment bubbles and sudden crashes occur in financial markets, and why online videos can gain millions of views in only a few hours.
　Psychologists emphasize, however, that simply following the majority is not always wise, because it can prevent people from making independent decisions based on evidence or reason. In other words, imitation can guide our choices in helpful directions, but it can also lead entire groups into serious mistakes when no one dares to question the crowd.
Japanese:
模倣は、社会的学習の過程と深く結びついており、人間が何を正しい、受け入れられる、または有用だと判断するかに強い影響を与えます。多くの人々がある考えを支持したり、特定の行動をとったりすると、他の人々はその行動をより合理的で価値のあるものと見なしやすくなります。同じ行動をとる人が多ければ多いほど、それを見ている人への影響力は強くなります。この傾向は、ファッショントレンドが急速に広まる理由や、金融市場で投資バブルや突然の暴落が起こる理由、さらにはオンライン動画が数時間で何百万回も再生される理由を説明しています。
　しかし心理学者たちは、ただ多数派に従うことが常に賢明とは限らないと強調しています。なぜなら、それは人々が証拠や理性に基づいた独立した判断を下すことを妨げる可能性があるからです。言い換えれば、模倣は私たちの選択を有益な方向へ導くこともありますが、誰も群衆に疑問を投げかけないとき、集団全体を深刻な誤りへと導くこともあるのです。

English:
One famous experiment by psychologist Albert Bandura in the 1960s provided striking evidence of the power of imitation. In the experiment, children observed an adult hitting, kicking, and shouting at an inflatable toy known as the “Bobo doll.” Later, when the children were given the same toy to play with, many of them repeated the aggressive actions they had just seen. This demonstrated that people, especially children, do not learn only by receiving instructions or rules, but also by copying the behaviors of others around them.
　From early human history, imitation helped groups survive, as copying the successful hunting methods or food-gathering techniques of experienced members increased the chances of survival. Even in the modern world, the same instinct shapes behavior, such as when travelers choose the busiest restaurant in an unfamiliar city, assuming that many customers must mean good quality. Television programs, advertisements, and social media platforms take advantage of this tendency by showing large numbers of people enjoying a product or activity, thereby encouraging others to follow along. Imitation, therefore, continues to influence human behavior on a daily basis, often in ways we do not even notice.

1960年代に心理学者アルバート・バンデューラが行った有名な実験は、模倣の力を強烈に示しました。この実験では、子どもたちが大人が膨らませた人形「ボボ人形」を叩いたり、蹴ったり、怒鳴ったりする様子を観察しました。その後、子どもたちに同じ人形を与えると、多くが見たばかりの攻撃的な行動を繰り返しました。これは、人間、特に子どもは、指示やルールを受け取ることだけで学ぶのではなく、周囲の他者の行動を真似ることによっても学ぶことを示しました。
　人類の初期の歴史においては、模倣は集団の生存を助けました。経験豊富な仲間の狩猟方法や採集技術を真似ることが、生き延びる可能性を高めたのです。現代社会においても、この本能は行動を形作ります。例えば、旅行者が知らない街で最も混んでいるレストランを選び、「多くの客がいるならきっと質が良いに違いない」と考えるときのように。テレビ番組、広告、そしてソーシャルメディアもまた、この傾向を利用しています。多くの人々がある商品や活動を楽しんでいる様子を示すことで、他の人々にも同じ行動を取るよう促すのです。したがって、模倣は今日においても、私たちの日常的な行動に影響を与え続けており、その多くは私たち自身が気づかないうちに働いているのです。
